text:
:bookmark_tabs: *Question about case studies: do you use first- or third-person language when writing yours?*

I’m thinking that first-person language (when mentioning your product/service/company) makes for a more personal tone, and the reader knows that it’s a case study on your website, possibly shared by your company’s sales reps. :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-4: But this could also remind the reader that, well, the case study was indeed written by someone paid by the company, and is inherently biased. :grimacing:

What’s the best practice here, and what do you find most impactful?

Many thanks. (edited)

elements.text: Question about case studies: do you use first- or third-person language when writing yours?

I’m thinking that first-person language (when mentioning your product/service/company) makes for a more personal tone, and the reader knows that it’s a case study on your website, possibly shared by your company’s sales reps.
But this could also remind the reader that, well, the case study was indeed written by someone paid by the company, and is inherently biased.

What’s the best practice here, and what do you find most impactful?

Many thanks. (edited)

text: Yep, I've seen this format work well for bigger companies. The State of Remote Work is a survey-based report. I'm looking to understand if any smaller startups have seen success with it. For example: Emily created the State of SaaS content marketing with publicly available data and it has over 150 strong backlinks <https://ek-byford.com/saas-content-marketing/>

attachments.title: The State of SaaS Content Marketing 2019 - Emily Byford
attachments.text: Does content marketing work in SaaS? I've analysed 500 of the world's biggest SaaS companies, to uncover their content marketing strategies.
attachments.fallback: Emily Byford: The State of SaaS Content Marketing 2019 - Emily Byford

text: Hi all ! For those of you who have hired freelance writers for multiple projects (i.e. 6+ number of pieces) - what is your expectation in terms of analytics provided? Do you just give them a creative brief, get the content back, make a few edits, and track it all yourself? Do you give them access to GA? I am curious as to how you gather meaningful insights from each piece of content created - and who tracks it all.

elements.text: Hi all ! For those of you who have hired freelance writers for multiple projects (i.e. 6+ number of pieces) - what is your expectation in terms of analytics provided? Do you just give them a creative brief, get the content back, make a few edits, and track it all yourself? Do you give them access to GA? I am curious as to how you gather meaningful insights from each piece of content created - and who tracks it all.

text: Generally speaking, most freelance writers aren’t equipped to check analytics on their own. You would have to give them access to GA or Ahrefs or whatever other tracking software you already have.

elements.text: Generally speaking, most freelance writers aren’t equipped to check analytics on their own. You would have to give them access to GA or Ahrefs or whatever other tracking software you already have.

text: Is it standard practice to do so

elements.text: Is it standard practice to do so

text:
in my 10 years freelancing i’ve only had 1 or 2 clients who gave me access to that data. others may have different experiences

I do wish more clients would do that, though. It helps me plan their content better and develop better pieces

elements.text:
in my 10 years freelancing i’ve only had 1 or 2 clients who gave me access to that data. others may have different experiences

text:
I'd wager that the skills sets (creative writing, analytics) have a fairly thin overlap. That overlap will probably increase over time but I'd never assume that someone who's solid with writing would also know the first thing about analytics or navigating+gleaning insight from GA.

(But if you do find someone with a strong overlap, consider them an asset!!)

elements.text:
I'd wager that the skills sets (creative writing, analytics) have a fairly thin overlap. That overlap will probably increase over time but I'd never assume that someone who's solid with writing would also know the first thing about analytics or navigating+gleaning insight from GA.

(But if you do find someone with a strong overlap, consider them an asset!!)

text: Thanks <@U01AHL8AGBB> and <@U016BDEQ40J> I am fortunate that I have a technical writer with the ability to navigate GA, but I am not sure how it fits in to his scope of work. My MarketingOps person is a hard worker but not as advanced as he is technically speaking so I am trying to find a way to maximize both of their strengths.

elements.text: Thanks
and

I am fortunate that I have a technical writer with the ability to navigate GA, but I am not sure how it fits in to his scope of work. My MarketingOps person is a hard worker but not as advanced as he is technically speaking so I am trying to find a way to maximize both of their strengths.

text: Set up a few A/B tests, and refresh some older content. Let them take this on as a pet project, and they can then both track the results over time. This way there is no pressure to asap rank new content, and they will surely learn from one another's insights and methods.

elements.text: Set up a few A/B tests, and refresh some older content. Let them take this on as a pet project, and they can then both track the results over time. This way there is no pressure to asap rank new content, and they will surely learn from one another's insights and methods.
